data.title: The Final Fantasy Preludes, Ranked
data.meta_description: It’s a simple composition; arpeggiated chords that go up and down, over and over again. But “Prelude” from Final Fantasy I sits alongside Super Mario Bros’ “World 1–1” and The Legend of Zelda’s…
data.text:
It’s a simple composition; arpeggiated chords that go up and down, over and over again. But “Prelude” from Final Fantasy I sits alongside Super Mario Bros’ “World 1–1” and The Legend of Zelda’s “Overworld” as one of the most iconic pieces of music in video game history. The legend goes that composer Nobuo Uematsu created it in ten minutes as a last-minute addition to the game — though considering the man would later casually string together around twenty distinct tunes for one of the great boss themes, it’s hardly a surprise that even his doodles would turn out to be timeless and iconic, subject to endless articles and analysis on the nature of his genius.

I’m not here to debate this, or to examine the evolution of one of Japan’s weirdest and most successful video game franchises. But it is interesting to see how this backbone of a theme has been built upon — and, in some cases, hopelessly distorted — by over thirty years of sequels, spin-offs, and sequels to spin-offs. In this respect, I’ll be sticking to the main series to make my life easier. Which means no Tactics, no Dissidia, and definitely not the time they added lyrics to it. Anyway, without further ado…
